div.div: Online access provides learning opportunities for students during COVID-19 shutdown

img.alt: Photo of students studying at home
img.p: In mid-March, as local school leaders were talking with Stanislaus County health officials about whether or not to shut down schools because of the coronavirus pandemic, Hughson Unified already was thinking ahead. So, when its four campuses were closed March 19 and more than 2,000 students were sent home, the district was prepared.

Teachers at all grade levels already had created enrichment plans so lessons could continue. At Hughson and Fox Road elementary schools, packets were sent home with each student with exercises to review as well as fun content. In grades four through 12, the district’s wise investment years ago in technology meant that each student had a Chromebook laptop computer to take home, enabling them to stay connected to teachers. For the roughly 300 families without Internet access, the district provided a free “mi-fi” connection in partnership with T-Mobile.
Classroom learning quickly transitioned to online learning.

“It’s very important to us that our students continue to learn and grow,” Hughson Superintendent Brenda Smith said. “It’s also important that parents keep them on a routine for school work and then exercise time during this beautiful weather. It’s also a good time to teach them a skill – to cook, change a tire or maybe to sew.”
Hughson Unified has about 1,500 Chromebooks, which are used day-to-day in most classes. Students regularly watch videos and complete assignments using various programs and educational websites.
“We use a lot of online learning programs, so we have access to digital content for reading, grammar, math and science,” said Eric Petersen, the principal at Fox Road Elementary School.
Luke Hibbard, principal at Ross Middle School, said the online work is “completely optional, but highly encouraged.”

No grades are being assigned at any level for the work, which is considered “enrichment,” building upon lessons that already have been presented in class during the school year. No new concepts are being introduced at this time.
Not grading material really is an “equity issue,” Hibbard explained. “One family may be worried about how they’re going to eat, while another could be focused on academics.”
There is no formal expectation of the amount of time students should spend on daily lessons, but two to three hours seems to be the common number.
“From what I can tell from families, it appears almost all of them are doing something,” Petersen said.

Take the 10-member Crayton family, for example. Five children of parents Sarah and Ron are affected by the closure of Hughson’s campuses – Gia, a high school senior; George, a junior; Lucas, a sophomore; Isabella, a sixth-grader; and Jack, a first-grader. Oldest daughter Nina, a sophomore at CSU Stanislaus, also is out of class. Four-year-old J.J. and 3-year-old Mario no doubt are enjoying the extra attention of their older siblings.

“We’re not sticking to a strict schedule,” said Sarah Crayton about daily lessons. “It’s usually two or three hours spread throughout the day. The older kids don’t require a lot of help. With our little guy, my husband or I try to go through three pages of math and three stories a day. Sometimes, his older brothers and sisters help him.”

Earlier this week, the children teamed up on an art project around the dining room table. Outside, they used chalk to draw pictures on their sidewalk to amuse neighbors. The family went for a walk together to the nearby arboretum. They planted a garden in the back yard. And they had a fun time responding to one of Hibbard’s daily social media challenges on the Ross Facebook page, submitting a family video of them doing burpees that got more than two dozen positive responses.
“It’s been fun,” said Sarah Crayton. “The junior high has done a good job of engaging them with exercise challenges and other things.”

All of Hughson’s campuses are using their Facebook pages to interact with students, parents and the community. Suggested lessons are posted and content exchanged. Students in a music class posted individual videos of themselves practicing. There is plenty of daily give and take. Teachers also are accessible via email, chat apps and blogs they post.
Still, social media can’t fill the void created by social distancing.
“Third-graders need their mother; 11th-graders need their friends,” summed up Hughson High Principal Loren Lighthall.

He said high school students’ comfort with technology makes distance learning comfortable for most, but “it’s hard to do a welding project online or to make sure kids are exercising 30 minutes a day.” Traditional testing, Lighthall admitted, also is impractical because "there’s no accountability to it” with students in one place and teachers in another.

Thursday, it was announced that the earliest school will reopen is May 4 – two weeks later than originally thought. And even that date is in flux based upon the health conditions at that time in Stanislaus County, which has had only about two dozen positive coronavirus cases so far.
School officials ask for patience as teachers work to create additional lessons that will be distributed soon.
“Parents have been really positive, but most are treading water at this point,” Lighthall said. “Until (Thursday), it was just three weeks and spring break. Now, it’s six weeks.”
Smith said the district will continue to do all it can to bridge the educational gap during this unprecedented time.

“I think Hughson was set up pretty well,” she said. “We have done about four years of professional development with a tech coach, so I felt like it was a pretty easy transition for our teachers. But nothing replaces face-to-face with a teacher.”
Sarah Crayton said she, her husband and their children intend to take full advantage of this “bonus” time together.
img.span: “It’s actually been nice,” she said. “There’s lots of family time. There are no practices or schedules; no appointments. We can go on walks together. And we can eat dinner at the same time – which never happens.”
